pull.title: cmake: Copy `cov_tool_wrapper.sh.in` to the build tree
pull.body:
This PR ensures that `cov_tool_wrapper.sh.in` is available when invoking the `Coverage.cmake` script from any directory.

Here is an example of usage on Ubuntu 24.10 with the default GCC 14.2.0:
```
$ cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="-fprofile-update=atomic" -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS="-fprofile-update=atomic"
$ cmake --build build -j $(nproc)
$ cd ..
$ cmake -DJOBS=$(nproc) -DLCOV_OPTS="--ignore-errors inconsistent,inconsistent" -P bitcoin/build/Coverage.cmake
```

Fixes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31638.

Looks very good to me. Thank you for the fix, and for pointing out & correcting the relative path issue.

One yes/vote, one question, one clarification..

_Yes/vote_ to move test execution to CMakeLists config via "ctest" targets. 
This resource is anyway legacy, and imagine it be supplanted by ctest targets.

_Question_ @hebasto: Since supplied fix has been refactored, will a cmake-only feature branch be available to acceptance test this?

_Clarification_ @theuni: The cmake tool suite practice: 

1. configure to cache 
2. build to the cache/build area
3. drive testing (ideally via "ctest" targets in CMakeLists config)

Unlike autotools, after step 1, accepted _cmake_ usage pattern is to be disconnected from source, meaning that extra resources, like this legacy wrapper, would need to already have been copied to cache during step 1.

comments.body: With the current design, the required `gcov` or `llvm-cov` tools are searched during the `Coverage{Fuzz}.cmake` script invocation. This two-step processing could potentially be avoided by moving these tool checks into the main buildsystem script. However, there is no reliable way to gate them depending on whether the build configuration is 'Coverage' or not.
